facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 512 of 1964 is an appeal from the judgment and decree dated December 23, 1960 of the Allahabad High Court in Income-tax Misc. Case No. 475 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 512 of 1964. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated December 23, 1960 of the Allahabad High Court in Income-tax Misc. Case No. 475 of 1954.

facts.text: Under an agreement dated January 2, 1931, Lab Manmohan Das (assessee) was appointed Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank Ltd. in respect of certain Branches, Sub-Agencies and Pay Offices.

anchor.surface_text: Under an agreement dated January 2, 1931, Lab Manmohan Das-hereinafter called the assessee-was appointed Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank Ltd. in respect of certain Branches, Sub-Agencies and Pay Offices.

facts.text: The assessee was assessed to income-tax as representing his Hindu undivided family, and the income received under the agreement was treated as income of the Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee was assessed to income-tax as representing his Hindu undivided family, and the income received by the assessee under the terms of the agreement with the Allahabad Bank, was treated as income of the Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: In the previous year corresponding to the assessment year 1950-51, the assessee suffered a net loss of Rs. 38,027 as Treasurer.

anchor.surface_text: In the previous year companyresponding to the assessment year 1950-51 the assessee in performing his duties as a Treasurer suffered a net loss of Rs. 38,027.

facts.text: For the assessment year 1951-52, the profit and loss account showed Rs. 73,815 as receipts against outgoings of Rs. 39,370 including Rs. 20,000 loss from misappropriation by Assistant Cashier at Patna Branch.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1951-52, the profit and loss account of the assesses showed Rs. 73,815 as receipts, against which were debited outgoings amounting to Rs. 39,370 which included Rs. 20,000 being the loss suffered by the assessee as Treasurer of the Patna Branch of the Allahabad Bank arising from misappropriation by an Assistant Cashier.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer refused to allow the loss of previous year to be set off against net profit of Rs. 34,445 and brought it to tax as remuneration.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer refused to allow the loss suffered in the previous year to be set off against the net profit of Rs. 34,445 and brought that amount of profit to tax as remuneration received by the assessee as Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed the Income-tax Officer's order in appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Income- tax Officer was companyflrmed in appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held remuneration was income from profession or vocation under s.10 and loss set-off allowed.

anchor.surface_text: The 5 33 Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held that the remuneration received by the assessee as Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank was income arising from pursuit of a profession or vocation within the meaning of s. 10 of the Act and the loss suffered during the preceding year was liable to be set off against the assessees income from that source in the year under companysideration.

facts.text: At instance of Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P., questions referred to Allahabad High Court under s.66(1) of Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P., the following questions were referred to the High Court of Allahabad under s. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act, 1922

facts.text: High Court held remuneration taxed under s.10 and set-off of 1950-51 loss against 1951-52 profit allowed.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the remuneration received by the from the Allahabad Bank was income liable to be taxed under s. 10 of the Income-tax Act, and that the assessee companyld claim to set off the loss companyputed in the assessment year 1950-51 against the profit in the subsequent year.

facts.text: Appeal preferred by Commissioner of Income-tax with certificate granted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: With certificate granted by the High Court, this appeal has been preferred by the Commissioner of Income-tax.

facts.text: For 1950-51 assessment, Income-tax Officer declared loss could not be carried forward under s.24 as not business loss.

anchor.surface_text: In making his order of assessment for the year 1950-51 the Income-tax Officer declared that the loss companyputed in that year companyld number be carried forward to the next year under s 24 2  of the Income-tax Act, as it was number a business loss.

facts.text: Agreement remuneration is monthly allowance total Rs. 2,250 plus Rs. 350 for travelling expenses.

anchor.surface_text: The remuneration of the. Treasurer shall be a monthly allowance for each of the Branches, SubAgencies and Pay Offices the total of such monthly allowance to be Rs. 2,250  Rupees two thousand two hundred and fifty  plus Rs. 350  Rupees three hundred fifty  for travelling expenses.

facts.text: Treasurer appoints Indian staff for Cash Department at salaries paid by Bank, with Bank approval, responsible for their acts.

anchor.surface_text: The Treasurer shall with the approval of the Bank appoint at adequate salaries to be paid by the Bank all the Indian staff as may be company- sidered sufficient by the Bank for the business of the Cash Department of the Banks Branches, Sub-Agencies and Pay Offices . . . and shall dismiss any person or persons so appointed whom he shall be reasonably directed by the Bank to dismiss

facts.text: Treasurer responsible to Bank for loss from embezzlement, theft, fraud, misappropriation, misconduct, mistake, omission, negligent act or default of staff.

anchor.surface_text: The Treasurer shall be responsible to the Bank for the work and companyduct of every person to be appointed or employed on his staff and shall make good to the Bank any loss or damage sustained or incurred by the Bank from any embezzlement, theft, fraud, misappropriation, misconduct, mistake, omission, negligent act or default of any such person or persons.

facts.text: Agreement terminable by three months notice by either party, binds heirs and representatives even after death for future claims.

anchor.surface_text: The Treasurers employment may be determined at any time by either party giving to the other three calendar months written numberice to that effect, and in case of the Treasurers death, this agreement as regards the Treasurers liabilities and obligations for the staff and other persons shall remain in force so as to bind his heirs, representatives and estate for any loss then accrued or accruing claim of the Bank hereunder but also for any future claim of the Bank in respect of any subsequent transaction or occurrence unless and 5 37 A until determined by his heirs or representatives giving like numberice to the Bank.

facts.text: Branches include Patna, Calcutta, Lahore, Lucknow, Amritsar, Benaras, Secunderabad.

anchor.surface_text: The Treasurer is under the agreement responsible for the acts of the Indian staff at the Branches, SubAgencies and Pay. Offices as far apart as Calcutta, Lahore, Lucknow, Patna, Amritsar, Benaras and Secunderabad.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Treasurer not a servant, remuneration not under s.7 but under s.10 as vocation.

anchor.surface_text: On a careful companysideration of the companyenants, we are of the view that the Treasurer was number a servant of the Allahabad Bank under the terms of the agreement dated January 2, 1931, and the remuneration received by him was number salaries within the meaning of s. 7 of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Loss in vocation under s.10 can be carried forward and set off under s.24(2).

anchor.surface_text: The remuneration must therefore be companyputed under s. IO of the Income-tax Act and loss of profit suffered in that vocation in any year may be carried forward to the next year and be set off against the profit of the succeeding year.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shah, J.

anchor.surface_text: V. Viswanatha Sastri, 4. Ganapathy lyer, R. H. Dhebar and R.N. Sachthey, for the appellant. T. Desai, and J. P. Goyal, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J.

The 5 33 Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held that the remuneration received by the assessee as Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank was income arising from pursuit of a profession or vocation within the meaning of s. 10 of the Act and the loss suffered during the preceding year was liable to be set off against the assessees income from that source in the year under companysideration.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on a true interpretation of the deed of agreement dated 2nd January, 1931, appointing the assessee as Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank Limited, income earned by the assessee from his activities as such Treasurer fell to be companyputed under Section 10 of the Act or Section 7 or Section 12 of the Income- tax Act ?

Taking into companysideration the nature of the duties performed, and the obligations undertaken, together with the right to remuneration subject to companypensation for loss arising to the Bank from his own acts and omissions or of the servants introduced by him into the business of the Bank, the assessee may be regarded as following a vocation.

concepts.interpretation: Occupation of Treasurer regarded as vocation based on duties, skill, guarantee against loss

concepts.unlisted_description: Occupation requiring skill and judgment with responsibility for losses

issues.text: Whether on a true interpretation of the deed of agreement dated 2nd January, 1931, appointing the assessee as Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank Limited, income earned by the assessee from his activities as such Treasurer fell to be computed under Section 10 of the Act or Section 7 or Section 12 of the Income-tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on a true interpretation of the deed of agreement dated 2nd January, 1931, appointing the assessee as Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank Limited, income earned by the assessee from his activities as such Treasurer fell to be computed under Section 10 of the Act or Section 7 or Section 12 of the Income- tax Act ?

issues.text: If the answer to this question is that such income is liable to be computed under Section 10 of the Act, Whether the assessee could claim a set off of the loss suffered by him in the preceding year 1950-51 against his profits in the year under consideration, i.e., 1951-52 having failed to prefer an appeal against the refusal by the Income-tax Officer making the assessment for the year 1950-51 to allow the assessee to carry forward the loss under Section 24(2) of the Act?

anchor.surface_text: If the answer to this question is that such income is liable to be computed under Section 10 of the Act, Whether the assessee could claim a set off of the loss suffered by him in the preceding year 1950-51 against his profits in the year under consideration, i.e., 1951-52 having failed to prefer an appeal against the refusal by the Income-tax Officer making the assessment for the year 1950-51 to allow the assessee to carry forward the loss under Section 24(2) of the Act ?

issues.text: Whether the assessee was a servant of the Bank under the terms of the agreement such that remuneration is computed under s.7 or an independent contractor carrying on a vocation under s.10?

anchor.surface_text: If the remuneration was received by the assessee as a servant of the Bank, and on that account has to be computed under s. 7 of the Act, the right to set off the loss cannot be claimed under s. 24(2).

issues.text: Whether the occupation of Treasurer constitutes a 'vocation' for the purposes of computation under s.10 and carry forward of loss under s.24(2)?

anchor.surface_text: On a careful consideration of the covenants, we are of the view that the Treasurer was not a servant of the Allahabad Bank under the terms of the agreement dated January 2, 1931, and the remuneration received by him was not salaries within the meaning of s. 7 of the Income-tax Act.

issues.text: Whether the Income-tax Officer's declaration in the prior year assessment that loss could not be carried forward under s.24(2) binds the assessee in the subsequent year?

anchor.surface_text: A decision recorded by the Income-tax Officer who computes the loss in the previous year under s. 24 3 that the loss cannot be set off against the income of the subsequent year is not binding on the assessee.

arguments.claim: s.24(2) confers statutory right to carry forward loss from business, profession or vocation and set off in subsequent year

anchor.surface_text: Section 24 2 confers a statutory right subject to certain conditions which are not material upon the assessee who sustains a loss of profits in any year in any business, profession or vocation to carry forward the loss as is not set off under sub-s. 1 to the following year, and to set it off against his profits and gains, if any, from the same business, profession or vocation for that year.

arguments.claim: Under the agreement, assessee was servant of Bank; remuneration computed under s.7, no set-off under s.24(2)

arguments.court_reasoning: Treasurer not servant; no right of control by Bank

arguments.claim: Treasurers under similar contracts are servants of Banks per Shivnandan Sharma and Piyare Lal precedents

anchor.surface_text: But Mr. Sastri on behalf of the Revenue contended relying upon Shivnandan Sharma v. The Punjab National Bank Ltd. and Piyare Lal Adishawar Lal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi, that under the contracts substantially similar to the contract in this case, Treasurers were held merely to be servants of the Banks, business whereof they attended.

arguments.court_reasoning: Contracts not identical; lacks control/supervision covenants present in those cases

arguments.claim: Treasurer not a servant under agreement; remuneration not salaries under s.7

anchor.surface_text: On a careful consideration of the covenants, we are of the view that the Treasurer was not a servant of the Allahabad Bank under the terms of the agreement dated January 2, 1931, and the remuneration received by him was not salaries within the meaning of s. 7 of the Income-tax Act.

arguments.claim: Occupation of Treasurer is a vocation; remuneration under s.10, loss carry forward under s.24(2)

anchor.surface_text: Taking into consideration the nature of the duties performed, and the obligations undertaken, together with the right to remuneration subject to compensation for loss arising to the Bank from his own acts and omissions or of the servants introduced by him into the business of the Bank, the assessee may be regarded as following a vocation.

arguments.claim: Master-servant relationship determined by right of control over manner of work

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra observed The principles according to which the relationship as between employer and employee or master and servant has got to be determined are well settled. The test which is uniformly applied in order to determine the relationship is the existence of a right of control in respect of the manner in which the work is to be done.

arguments.claim: Agreement is contract for service, not contract of service; distinction based on control over how work is done

anchor.surface_text: A distinction is also drawn between a contract for service and a contract of service and that distinction is put in this way. In the one case the master can order or require what is to be done while in the other case he can not only order or require what is to be done but how itself it shall be done.

arguments.claim: Shivnandan Sharma case distinguishable as contract had Bank control over Treasurer and staff

anchor.surface_text: In Shivnandan Sharmas case the covenants reposed direction and control over Shivnandan and ministerial staff in the Bank. Treasurer agreed to obey orders, bound by rules; Bank could dispense services forthwith.

arguments.claim: Piyare Lal case distinguishable due to Bank's direct control and summary dismissal power

holdings.text: A decision recorded by the Income-tax Officer who computes the loss in the previous year under s. 24(3) that the loss cannot be set off against the income of the subsequent year is not binding on the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: A decision recorded by the Income-tax Officer who computes the loss in the previous year under s. 24 3 that the loss cannot be set off against the income of the subsequent year is number binding on the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.24(2) right to carry forward and set off loss from same source determined in assessment of subsequent year by that year's ITO; prior computation under s.24(3) not binding.

holdings.text: The Treasurer was not a servant of the Allahabad Bank under the terms of the agreement dated January 2, 1931, and the remuneration received by him was not salaries within the meaning of s. 7 of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: On a careful companysideration of the companyenants, we are of the view that the Treasurer was number a servant of the Allahabad Bank under the terms of the agreement dated January 2, 1931, and the remuneration received by him was number salaries within the meaning of s. 7 of the Income-tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of Bank control over manner of work; contract for service not of service; distinguished Shivnandan Sharma and Piyare Lal precedents lacking identical control/supervision covenants.

holdings.text: Taking into consideration the nature of the duties performed, and the obligations undertaken, together with the right to remuneration subject to compensation for loss arising to the Bank from his own acts and omissions or of the servants introduced by him into the business of the Bank, the assessee may be regarded as following a vocation. The remuneration must therefore be computed under s. 10 of the Income-tax Act and loss of profit suffered in that vocation in any year may be carried forward to the next year and be set off against the profit of the succeeding year.

anchor.surface_text: Taking into companysideration the nature of the duties performed, and the obligations undertaken, together with the right to remuneration subject to companypensation for loss arising to the Bank from his own acts and omissions or of the servants introduced by him into the business of the Bank, the assessee may be regarded as following a vocation. The remuneration must therefore be companyputed under s. IO of the Income-tax Act and loss of profit suffered in that vocation in any year may be carried forward to the next year and be set off against the profit of the succeeding year.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Treasurer role involves skill, judgment, supervision, and personal guarantee for losses; qualifies as vocation permitting computation under s.10 and s.24(2) set-off; not profession or business.

precedents.cited_proposition: Principles for determining employer-employee relationship; test of right of control over manner of work; distinction between contract for service and contract of service.
precedents.cited_holding: The nature or extent of control requisite to establish employer-employee relationship varies and is a question of fact based on circumstances; greater control indicates contract of service.

precedents.cited_proposition: It is impossible to lay down any rule of law distinguishing contract for service from contract of service; question of fact based on circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: Taking into companysideration the nature of the duties performed, and the obligations undertaken, together with the right to remuneration subject to companypensation for loss arising to the Bank from his own acts and omissions or of the servants introduced by him into the business of the Bank, the assessee may be regarded as following a vocation. The remuneration must therefore be companyputed under s. IO of the Income-tax Act and loss of profit suffered in that vocation in any year may be carried forward to the next year and be set off against the profit of the succeeding year.
